div.p: Greetings. I am briefer than ever, I write only this, reverend father in Christ, so that you may understand that yours have been delivered to me. I have nothing new at all.
The commissioners have not yet returned.

If Märius has not come, he will come; for he himself, after asking me to write this, has gone to his village and perhaps stayed there for this eight-day period. We have heard from France what you write, not without great joy; the same is announced from elsewhere. Regarding the Five Cantons, I see there is not much to hope for; Landammann Bäldius writes to me and urges that I encourage our people to assist if any force is used against them, which is for me a sign that things are in a very bad state with them. We are more occupied than ever before with the bishop's business.
We have been writing these days continuously; at the same time, we will instruct the good people about the Glarus business. This whole matter is the Lord's, who will undoubtedly act.

If anything worthy of knowledge is written from Frankfurt, I humbly ask you to share it out of your kindness towards us. I know your occupations; therefore, assign the task of replying to my relative Theodor.
Farewell, most illustrious man, with all your people, as happily as possible. Chur, April 13, in the year of our Lord 1561.
Your most observant Johannes Fabricius. After I had written this, the commissioners return.

Mr. Friedrich writes, but adds nothing new in the letters; nevertheless, I send them so that you may see that I have diligently taken care of all your matters; return the letters when it is convenient. Francis Portus Graecus also writes, from whose letter I have noted what you see on the attached sheet. Farewell again.
To the most illustrious man, excellent in learning and piety, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant Antistes of the Church of Zürich, his much-honored lord and patron.
